item.title: Ticket #8446 (Using Slug-Data in CSS Classes does not work) created
item.dc:creator: lilyfan
item.description:
post_class() function outputs category/tag specific classes using its slug (introduced at [8641]).

But, allowed characters are different between slug and css class name. (css class name can use [-_a-zA-Z0-9] and non ascii unicod chars)

A "%" character is allowed for slug, but not for css name.

Therefore, invalid class name will be created.

Eg: A user creates "携帯" category (Japanese word for "mobile"), the category slug will be "%e6%90%ba%e5%b8%af" and post_class() outputs 'class="post hentry category-%e6%90%ba%e5%b8%af"'. This is an invalid class name.

Avoid this situation, escaping "%" character with backslash "\": category-\%e6\%90\%ba\%e5\%b8\%af" This class name is valid. But this seems dirty.

I suggest using class ID insted of class slug.

item.title: Ticket #8445 (Improve backend styling (Settings pages)) created
item.dc:creator: Alphawolf
item.description:
Hey there, searched for a while now, but couldn't find something similar already, so here's a ticket for ya.

I was wondering if there's still styling improvements planned. I'm using the 27-almost-rc revision, and some Settings pages like options-general.php or, even worse, options-writing.php which look tremendously ugly and unstructured to my eyes. In 2.5/2.6 a "settings group" had a blueish background to seperate each, which improved the UI drastically IMO.

It just seems that styles for the e.g. 'form-table' class were gone in 2.7.

item.title: Ticket #8443 (Reorder sans-serif font family declaration) created
item.dc:creator: iammattthomas
item.description:
From the testers list:

"Is it just me, or is the Bitstream Vera Sans font particularly ugly on Windows machines? Personally, I much preferred Verdana which, I think I'm right in saying, was the font up until a few builds ago."

The attached patch re-orders the font families declared to read Lucida Grande, Verdana, Arial, Bistream Vera Sans.

item.title: Ticket #8441 (New Widget API based on MultiWidget Class) updated
item.dc:creator: thornomad
item.description: Cc changed

item.title: Ticket #8441 (New Widget API based on MultiWidget Class) created
item.dc:creator: thornomad
item.description:
I have a feature enhancement for consideration in the trunk -- not sure how to go about getting it in there, so I thought I would post it here.

This came about when I tried to add mult-widget functionaility to a plugin I was contributing to ... I found the process to be far from easy and, although I got it to work, it required a lot of clunky coding.

Alex Tingle (lead devloper on the plugin) agreed, and created this enhancement to reduce the clunk: a php class called MultiWidget. The class handles all the nefarious multi-widget "tricks" required to implement a multi-widget plugin.

The benefit is that it will provide widget developers with a clean way to extend their plugins to multi-widget functionality without things "getting ugly" (as I see it).

See blog post explaining this at: ​http://blog.firetree.net/2008/11/30/wordpress-multi-widget/

See the code for this at: ​http://ec3.pastebin.com/fccfe0a0

See example usage of this class at: ​http://ec3.pastebin.com/f56a1539d

Again, not sure how to get it considered for inclusion in the Wordpress trunk, but I think it would benefit countless widget developers who, like me, run into some barriers when implementing a multi-widget.

Thanks, Damon

item.title: Ticket #8440 (Consider moving Bitstream Vera Sans after Verdana again) created
item.dc:creator: demetris
item.description:
Bitstream Vera Sans is not an uncommon font in Windows. According to this:

​http://www.codestyle.org/css/font-family/sampler-WindowsResultsFull.shtml

... it is found in 25% of Windows systems.

So, in those systems, instead of the ideal and recently introduced Verdana, Bitstream Vera Sans will be used now, which is nowhere near Verdana as a web font.

I happened to notice this on three different Windows computers in the last couple of days. (I don’t know which program or programs install Bitstream Vera in Windows. Probably OpenOffice is one -- it was common in all three installations.)

Relevant changeset: ​http://trac.wordpress.org/changeset/9918

item.title: Ticket #8439 (wp_page_menu produces invalid html when used multiple times in a page ...) created
item.dc:creator: corischlegel
item.description:
wp_page_menu() produces a div with an id attribute. If the template tag is placed multiple times in a page (say in the header and footer, for example) this will produce invalid html (in HTML 4 id must be unique in a document: ​http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-html40/struct/global.html#adef-id). In addition, the defaults use the key "menu_class", which is misleading if the generated html actually produces an id.

Attached patch swaps "<div id=" for "<div class=", and fixes both problems.

item.title: 8438-dash-links-hitzone.png attached to Ticket #8438
item.dc:creator: janbrasna
item.description: Comparison of current and ideal hit-zone

item.title: Ticket #8438 (Dashboard Right Now links hard to hit.) created
item.dc:creator: janbrasna
item.description:
The hit-zone for the main «Right Now» links is too small (only the number itself). Ideally the whole area should be clickable (refer to ​http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fitts%27_law ...). The attachment demonstrates that.

However I see that the current markup doesn't allow for an easy change to accommodate a bigger hit-zone. Yet, opening a ticket with the hope to find a solution to resolve the issue.

item.title: Ticket #8417 (fav-arrow.png disrupts favourites menu background in IE6) updated
item.dc:creator: ydekproductions
item.description:
It's a well known defect that can be fixed by patching it.

You guys could just slap in the ​jQuery pngFix to fix most of the problems. But the sprite sheets will have to be excluded from the fix.

The AlphaImageLoader object cannot handle the background-position attributes. So using a png sprite sheet is impossible to work on IE6.

Been there, done that, got angry about it. :)

item.title: Ticket #8417 (fav-arrow.png disrupts favourites menu background in IE6) closed
item.dc:creator: azaozz
item.description:
wontfix:

This is because of the inability of IE6 to handle PNG images with alpha channel (it's a "last millennium" browser after all). It's a well known defect that can be fixed by patching it.

item.title: Ticket #8431 (Publish button gives 404) updated
item.dc:creator: azaozz
item.description:
Keywords changed

That's strange. There is action=edit in post.php: ​http://trac.wordpress.org/browser/trunk/wp-admin/post.php#L120

post.php handles the redirects after publishing or saving a post depending on where it comes from (same for page.php for pages). Perhaps try reverting any changes to post-new, edit-form-advanced and post.php, then put an var_dump($_POST);exit; just before the redirect to see what's going on.

item.description: Updated patch for theme-editor.php revision 9903

item.title: Ticket #8433 (Profile contains options that don't apply to users with "subscriber" role) created
item.dc:creator: jivany
item.description:
For a user with the "subscriber" role, the Profile page contains three options under the "Personal Options" heading:

  • Visual Editor
  • Admin Color Scheme
  • Keyboard Shortcuts

"Visual Editor" does not apply to a subscriber as they cannot write posts. This option does not need to be presented to a subscriber.

"Admin Color Scheme" is redundant as the two options presented to the subscriber are the same (both the "bold" and "subtle" colour options are the same).

"Keyboard Shortcuts" does not apply to a subscriber as they are not able to moderate comments.

Observed in Version 2.7-almost-rc-9965

item.title: Ticket #8432 ("Dashboard > Tools > Press This" visible to users with "subscriber" role) created
item.dc:creator: jivany
item.description:
Blog users with subscriber role are presented with the "Press This" bookmarklet on the Tools page. The bookmarklet is not usable by a subscriber so it doesn't make sense to provide them this functionality.

Observed in 2.7-almost-rc-9965

item.title: Ticket #8431 (Publish button gives 404) updated
item.dc:creator: mrmist
item.description: Not seeing this in 9981. Publish and update are working properly. Have you done an svn revert on your edited files to ensure it's not your changes making this happen?

item.title: Ticket #8431 (Publish button gives 404) created
item.dc:creator: gboyers
item.description:
When I hit the "publish" or "update post" button in WordPress 2.7-almost-rc-9965 when either writing or editing a post, it returns me to the 'edit posts' list, and doesn't save the post at all.

I have to manually save a post (not publish), then quick-edit the post to change its status to published. Autosave came in very handy when I first discovered this problem.

This problem comes after I fixed a previous error. Hitting publish would send me to post.php (instead of edit.php) which got a 404. I edited post.php out of edit-posts.php (i believe) and replaced it with edit.php, which then worked properly until the next SVN update (i believe).

I have updated via SVN to 9981 with no difference, and even restored the relevant PHP files: edit.php edit-pages.php and edit-page-form.php to try and correct this issue.

item.title: Ticket #8414 (No UI feedback when a new Page is published) updated
item.dc:creator: kpdesign
item.description:
Mrmist is right - it is still broken. There are status messages for the minor actions (Save as Draft, Save as Pending Review), but no status message for the major action "Publish".

Tested this on latest revision (9978) with the following results:

  • Add new page, save as Draft: status message at top "Page updated". Taken to Edit Page, still see page trying to be created.
  • Add new page, save as Pending Review: status message "Page updated". Taken to Edit Page, still see page trying to be created.
  • Add new page, click Publish: no status message at all. Taken to "Add New Page" (url: ​http://****/wordpress27/wp-admin/page-new.php?posted=29). The URL is the only thing that tells you that the page was published.
  • Edit page just created, change status back to Draft: status message at top "Page updated. Continue editing below or go back.". Still on Edit Page, still see page being edited.
  • Edit page just created, change status back to Pending Review: status message at top "Page updated. Continue editing below or go back.". Still on Edit Page, still see page being edited.
  • Edit page just created, status either draft or pending review, click Publish: no status message at all. Taken to "Add New Page" (url: ​http://****/wordpress27/wp-admin/page-new.php?posted=29). Once again, the URL is the only thing that tells you that the page was published.

item.title: Ticket #8021 (Firefox spell checker not working in contentEditable areas) updated
item.description:
Futher ....

FF: New Post -> "This hgdhs test" -> Nothing checked.

FF: New Post -> "hgdhs this test" -> 'hgdhs' highlighted

FF: New Post -> "hgdhs test shdg" -> 'hgdhs' highlighted

If you click the Spell Check button twice, both 'hgdhs' and 'shdg' are highlighted.

In IE, you only have to click the button once, and both will be highlighted.

item.title: Ticket #8021 (Firefox spell checker not working in contentEditable areas) reopened
item.description:
Sorry, what? What was fixed? It exhibits the exact same behavior on FF/Win ... no change whatsoever.

Firefox: New Post -> "This is a hgihd test" -> Nothing spell checked. Firefox: New Post -> "hgihd This is a test" -> 'hgihd' highlighted IE : New Post -> "This is a hgihd test" -> Nothing checked. IE : New Post -> "hgihd This is a test" -> Nothing checked.

So now the question is --- is it supposed to auto-check? Or are you supposed to hit the button? Because now you guys are saying it's fixed, when no behavior has changed. ;-)

item.title: Ticket #8119 (Attempts to edit deleted categories are not properly handled) updated
item.dc:creator: mrmist
item.description:
The above warnings and errors were produced without WP_DEBUG.

With regards to version I reproduced this last night when the svn was up to 9668 I think. Doesn't look like I noted down the original svn revision but I guess it's safe to say that this code hasn't ever changed, because the case to produce it is not that frequently seen.

In case I've not been clear in this note that this is not just about deleting or editing categories. That works just fine and dandy. This is about a situation where you have two concurrent users working on the same category. So, for the sake of reproduction for test purposes it would be -

  1. Log on in one browser as a user, go to categories.php
  2. Log on in another browser as a different user, go to categories.php
  3. As one of the users, delete a category.
  4. As the other user, now attempt to edit the category that was just deleted.

In normal edit, the edit screen now appears, but it's obviously not populated because the cat has been deleted. There's no message to indicate that the category has been deleted, though. (Such as you get if you try to edit a deleted page/post). Instead you get warnings at the top as I noted in my previous comment.

  1. Fill in the edit category box anyway, and press edit category and you get the message "Your attempt to edit this category: "" has failed." You can go back, but you cannot (successfully) progress from the edit category screen.

I cannot reliably reproduce the error message condition which I originally referred to.

If you additionally enable wp_debug, you get the following notices on the edit cat page -

br /><b>Notice</b>: Trying to get property of non-object in <b>/home/www/htdocs/svn/trunk/wp-admin/edit-category-form.php</b> on line <b>52</b><br />

For lines 57,63,69 as well.

Then on the Error page -

Notice: Undefined property: WP_Error::$name in /home/www/htdocs/svn/trunk/wp-includes/category.php on line 201

item.title: Ticket #8357 (RSS Widget does not parse Google feeds correctly) updated
item.dc:creator: jtatum
item.description:
Cc, Keywords changed

The problem is not the rel=alternate tag. The problem is actually that Google Reader adds a source tag: 

        <source gr:stream-id="feed/http://twistedrat.blogspot.com/atom.xml">
            <id>tag:google.com,2005:reader/feed/http://twistedrat.blogspot.com/atom.xml</id>
            <title type="html">BreakMusicBlog</title>
            <link rel="alternate" href="http://twistedrat.blogspot.com/" type="text/html"/>
        </source>

The diff adds some hooks to detect the beginning and end of this source tag in a Google Reader RSS feed. When encountered, it will toggle a flag to tell the parser to ignore links, titles, and other data encountered in this section.

item.title: Ticket #8417 (fav-arrow.png disrupts favourites menu background in IE6) updated
item.dc:creator: ydekproductions
item.description:
I think that's looking like you're describing because you aren't using 32bit colors in Windows.

I know if I boot up Windows in VMWare, it's set at 16bit by default, which causes anything with transparency to render a little bit weird.

Wanna post a screenshot?

item.title: Ticket #7084 (Widget titles need to be auto-escaped.) updated
item.dc:creator: jtatum
item.description: The attached patch implements the widget_title filter. A quick scan of widgets.php shows that most widgets invoke this filter for the widget title, however it is not implemented by default. Figuring that titles for widgets would be similar to most other titles, this is generally used in a way similar to the blog's title, this small diff applies the same filter sets as are applied to wp_title.

item.title: default-filters.php.diff attached to Ticket #7084
item.dc:creator: jtatum
item.description: Implementing widget_title filter
